paper.core_task: Enhancing transferable adversarial attacks on Vision Transformers

contributions.name: Gradient Normalization Scaling (GNS) method
contributions.author_claim_text: We present a novel Gradient Normalization Scaling and High Frequency Adaptation(GNS-HFA) method to enhance the transferability of adversarial samples on ViTs.
contributions.description: A novel method called Gradient Normalization Scaling (GNS) is proposed to edit gradients at a fine-grained level, aiming to scale mild gradients to prevent overfitting during adversarial sample training and improve transferability.

contributions.name: High-Frequency Adaptation (HFA) method
contributions.author_claim_text: The proposed method addresses the challenge of gradient variations during backpropagation process by normalizing and scaling the gradients, as well as constructing masks to explore the impact of attacks in different frequency regions on ViTs.
contributions.description: The High-Frequency Adaptation (HFA) method is introduced, which leverages the insight that ViTs focus on high-frequency features. It uses frequency domain exploration and masking to enhance the transferability of adversarial attacks.

novelty_claims.text:
As shown in Table 1, we constructed the adversarial samples on the CaiT-S/24
model by removing mild gradients and extreme gradients respectively, and
calculated the average attack success rate after these adversarial samples
were transferred to attack other ViT and CNN models.

The contribution is marginal, since the gradient normalization was
demonstrated in [1], please discuss the major differences.

In order to enhance the transferability of adversarial attacks on ViTs, this
paper introduces a novel gradient normalization scaling method for fine-
grained gradient editing.
This paper comes up with a novel problem space.

As shown in **Figure 2 in the paper** , removing ‘mild gradients’ results in a
greater improvement in attack success rate compared to removing ‘extreme
gradients’, indicating that ‘mild gradients’ are more prone to overfitting,
thereby affecting the training of adversarial samples on the surrogate model.
